owl:Ontology.terms:description: Simple ontology for Cloud Computing Services. This ontology allows to define model of prices used in large cloud computing providers such as Google, Amazon, Azure, etc., including options for regions, type of instances, prices specification, etc.
owl:Ontology.terms:title: Vocabulary in Cloud Computing Services
owl:Ontology.rdfs:label: Cloud Computing Services Ontology

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The power or capacity of CPU available for this type of VM.

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: For Google Cloud, cost of SQL server image is charged on per core basis.
Similar to location, this property specifies the continent.
Google Cloud OS price for VM with different number of cores are different. It is used to describe price for machines with less than or equal to the specified number of cores.
Google Cloud OS price for VM with different number of cores are different. This is used to describe the price for machines with more than specified number of cores.
For Google Cloud, cores and vCPU referes to the same thing.

Some examples of spetial rates from Google: Egress between zones in the same region (per GB) is 0.01. Egress between regions within the US (per GB) is 0.01. Egress to Google products (such as YouTube, Maps, Drive), whether from a VM in GCP with an external IP address or an internal IP address is no charge.
State Abbreviations can be described using this property, like Azure/us-west region is in CA

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: This class can be used to model network services prices, including internet egress traffic, load balancing forwarding rules.

owl:Axiom.rdfs:comment: i.e. Egress between zones in the same region; Egress between regions within the US; Egress to Google products (such as YouTube, Maps, Drive)
Describe the price for machines with more than specified number of cores.

For example on Google Cloud, Windows Server images on some machine types are charged based on the number of CPUs, i.e., n1-standard-4, n1-highcpu-4, and n1-highmem-4 are machine-types with 4 vCPUs, and are charged at $0.16 USD/hour (4 times $0.04 USD/hour).
https://github.com/miranda-zhang/cloud-computing-schema/blob/master/example/gcloud/os.md#windows-server-images
Describe price for machines with less than orequal to the specified number of cores.
Price specification for Cloud Service

Region can either be associated with price or a type of service. So Region can be specified either within CloudService class and subclasses, or in UnitPriceSpecification. For example, when the service has different priced in different regions, regions are associated with price; when there are lots of measurements for the service in a region, region can be associated with service.
CloudNetworkPriceSpecification use other properties to sepecify destination
gr:hasCurrencyValue seems only allow float value, extend to allow xs:decimal, which can represent exact monetary values. Floats can introduce cumulative rounding errors.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Can be used to define a common price spec for multiple cloud service individuals, i.e. the storage transaction spec has a different price in a different region, but there is a common transaction price spec for a group of cloud storage offers.

owl:Axiom.rdfs:comment: Local storage available on this VM, or netowrk storage attached to this VM.
Size of Memory

VM storage transaction price specification. There is a data access fees on local disk of Azure VM. For example, every single block access incurs a transaction. The default block size is 4 Megabytes, meaning uploading a 32Mb file will incur 8 Storage Transactions. Deleting the file will also incur 8 transactions, so will updating it, and any other time the file is touched. The transactions are charged at a cost of around $0.00036 USD per 10,000 transactions. So 32Mb file will cost $0.000000368 AUD. The only exception to Storage Transactions is when Premium Storage (persistent SSD storage) is used. That is, when you provision a P10, P20 or a P30 disk for your Virtual Machine those disks are exempt from Storage Transactions.
https://github.com/miranda-zhang/cloud-computing-schema/blob/master/example/azure/vm.md#storage-transactions
CPU power of VM
Google specifies the maximum number of disk allowed to attach to a VM.
Google also specifies the maximum total disk size allowed to attach to a VM.
The number of cores available on this VM.
Exact location take precedence over large area, i.e. Geo coordinates is better than city and country name.

owl:Axiom.terms:modified: We store the string representation of ipv4 for human readability, instead of unsigned 32 bit numbers.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Storage that is not detachable from VM
QoS stats can be stored as Measurements. This is an equivalent class to sosa:Observation.
Storage can exist independent from VM
Platform as a Service, i.e. Google App Engine, Heroku.
This is an equivalent class to ssn-system:SystemProperty. QoS is more understandable in our context, and we can group related classed under this base class.

owl:Axiom.rdfs:comment: Some regions can be in multiple locations, i.e. nam-eur-asia1, they can be in multiple jurisdictions. Other region should have at most 1 phisical location associated with it.

If a definite location or address is known, physical location can be set, otherwise cocoon:inJurisdiction can be used to describe where it is in approximately. The intended usage of this is record the known most precise location.
For example, Google Cloud Composer.
Available snapshot options.
Disks can have different input/output operations per sec (IOPs).
Disks can have different throughput caps, i.e. 200 MB/second

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A system image is a serialized copy of the entire state of a computer system. System images can be used for backup.
Directions of internet data tranfer, or load balancing data. Can be either Ingress or Egress.
Defines custome units. This is an equivalent class to qudt:Unit.

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Gigabyte (GB): There are 1024MB in one gigabyte.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gigabyte

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Often describe 1 GB per Hour usage.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gigabyte per Hour

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Often describe 1 GB per Month usage.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Gigabyte per Month

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: GCEU (Google Compute Engine Unit), or GQ for short, is a unit of CPU capacity that we use to describe the compute power of our instance types. We chose 2.75 GQ's to represent the minimum power of one logical core (a hardware hyper-thread) on our Sandy Bridge platform.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Google Compute Engine Unit

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Azure Managed Disks provide different input/output operations per sec (IOPs)
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Input/output operations per sec

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Azure Ultra SSD Managed Disks come in different sizes that provide a configurable range of input/output operations per sec (IOPS), and are billed on an hourly rate.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: IOPS/hour

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Often describe the throughput usage measured at MB/s within an hour.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: MB/s/hour

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Terabyte is more precisely defined as 1,024 gigabytes (GB)
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Terabyte

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Azure Ultra SSD storage is in preview in East US 2 and is billed on vcpu/hour provisioned as reservation charge. This reservation charge is only imposed if you enable Ultra SSD capability on the VM without connecting an Ultra SSD disk.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: vcpu/hour
